Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Learning from Coarse, Nonmetric, and Incomplete Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent years, we have witnessed an explosion in the amounts of data being acquired and analyzed in a wide variety of contexts. Data-driven techniques are increasingly applied, not only in the traditional quantitative sciences, but also throughout the social sciences and in a variety of other non-traditional scenarios that challenge many of our common assumptions. For example, in contexts such as collaborative filtering, personalized and predictive medicine, and personalized learning systems, we face a variety of challenges due largely to the fact that an important -- often the only -- source of data is people. In these and many other modern applications, we want to learn about people using the data that people supply.

This presents several difficulties, including the fact that such data is often very "coarse" or heavily "quantized". It might even be binary or entirely nonmetric data consisting of categories or comparisons. Moreover, in many of these cases it is impossible to fully sample the data, and the underlying data of interest may be constantly changing, necessitating approaches that can handle incomplete observations and dynamic data models. This research confronts these difficulties by building on recent progress in the design of efficient algorithms for exploiting low-dimensional structure to perform inference, often using highly incomplete and coarse observations. This research addresses a number of fundamental theoretical and algorithmic questions in the context of low-rank matrix recovery, nonmetric multidimensional scaling, unfolding, and low-dimensional dynamic models. It has applications in contexts such as collaborative filtering, personalized and predictive medicine, and personalized learning systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A defining feature of many modern machine learning systems is the role of cooperation between a machine learning algorithm and a human providing supervision to the algorithm. The prototypical example of this kind of cooperation involves providing a set of features (e.g., an image) to a human and receiving precise supervision such as a class label or some precise numerical quantity describing the features. In practice, such precise feedback can be extremely difficult for people to supply, and as a result it often presents difficulties such as being "quantized" to rough numerical ranges or instead consisting of relative comparisons between different items (e.g., according to how similar or preferred different items are relative to each other).  Moreover, in such cases it is often expensive if not impossible to "fully sample" the data as doing so would require large amounts of time of the people providing this information.

In this research we addressed several fundamental questions related to both theory and algorithms for learning from such "coarse" and "incomplete" data.

First, we answered several theoretical questions related to the problem of matrix completion. In this problem our data can be represented as a matrix which exhibits some kind of structure (e.g., it is low rank) and we see only a few of the entries of the matrix and wish to fill in the missing entries. Such scenarios arise in the context of recommendation systems, personalized learning systems, and many other applications. In this work we developed the first theoretical and algorithmic approaches for matrix completion when the underlying matrix is dynamically evolving over time (as frequently happens in practice). We also provided a novel analysis of how effectively we can complete a low rank matrix when the observations are corrupted with Poisson noise, which arises when the data consist of event counts.

Second, we studied a number of problems related to learning from paired comparisons. In particular, in one common model of human preference, we begin with a representation of many possible items as points in some low-dimensional space of features. A person's preference for each item is then determined by the distance between the item and a so-called ideal point that represents a set of features corresponding to a hypothetical ideal item. In this project we provided the first theoretical guarantees for how accurately we can estimate this ideal point from comparisons of the form "item A is preferred over item B". We also developed an adaptive algorithm for choosing which items to present to the user so as to identify this point in as few queries as possible, resulting in state-of-the-art performance. Finally, we have also extended these techniques to be able to dynamically track an ideal point as it varies over time.

Finally, leveraging techniques from the works above, we also developed a state-of-the-art system for learning to predict student responses to homework problems based on both the student's history as well as that of other students. This will have applications in both the practical context of designing autonomous personalized learning systems as well as providing a platform to help in answering fundamental questions in cognitive science.
